page.title: 07 HIGHCLIFFE CASTLE
page.content: The castle was a beautiful building but sadly fires damaged it in 1967 and 1968 and it is now falling down. In the 19th century Highcliffe Castle was built to replace an earlier mansion built by John, 3rd Earl of Bute in 1770.The present Castle was started by his grandson, Lord Stuart de Rothesay in 1830. It took him four years to build. In Victorian times the village was called Newtown, but in 1892 it was renamed Highcliffe after the castle. On the 1st January 1977 Christchurch Council took control of the house and the grounds of the castle. In June 1977, to celebrate the Silver Jubilee of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, the grounds were opened to the public. At the castle today people can walk in the grounds and follow a footpath to the beach. By Sally Skeldon,Lucy and Katie Hicks.
